title-group.article-title: Using Logistic Approximations of Marginal Trace Lines to Develop Short Assessments

article-meta.aff: 2University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, USA

author-notes.corresp: Brian D. Stucky, RAND Corporation, 1776 Main Street, P.O. Box 2138, Santa Monica, CA 90407, USA Email: bstucky@rand.org

abstract.p: Test developers often need to create unidimensional scales from multidimensional data. For item analysis, marginal trace lines capture the relation with the general dimension while accounting for nuisance dimensions and may prove to be a useful technique for creating short-form tests. This article describes the computations needed to obtain logistic approximations of marginal trace lines for graded response items derived from multidimensional bifactor item response theory (IRT) models. Next, the properties of marginal-trace-line-based likelihoods are evaluated and compared with other bifactor IRT methods. It is noted that for the dimension of interest, the likelihoods computed from marginal item response functions are not equivalent to the conditional likelihoods from the multidimensional IRT model. The authors then propose a method that evaluates the degree of item-level dimensionality and allows for the selection of subsets of items (i.e., short form) that result in scaled scores and standard errors that are equivalent to other multidimensional IRT-based scoring procedures. Finally, a real-data application is provided, which illustrates the utility of logistic approximations of marginal trace lines in the creation of a content-diverse short form.

body.p: In scale construction, researchers are often interested in developing unidimensional scales, but are faced with multidimensional data. To account for multidimensionality or nuisance local dependence (LD), bifactor item response theory (IRT) models (Gibbons & Hedeker, 1992) are increasingly being used in psychological (Thissen & Steinberg, 2010), health (Reeve et al., 2007; Reise, Morizot, & Hays, 2007), and educational research settings (Bradlow, Wainer, & Wang, 1999). However, there has yet to be a technique formally proposed that allows a unidimensional scale of items to be extracted from a larger bifactor model. For graded response items, this article proposes the use of marginal trace lines as a method for capturing the relationship between the general dimension and the item response, while simultaneously accounting for the nuisance association with the secondary dimension. Evaluation of the properties of marginal trace lines reveals when they should and should not be used, and how, when used properly, they can be effective in developing diverse, unidimensional short forms measuring primary dimensions of bifactor IRT models.

This article first discusses the bifactor model as a technique for accounting for LD while capturing the association with the general dimension. Next, extending the work of Ip (2010a, 2010b) to graded response items, the authors provide the necessary computations for obtaining the bifactor IRT-based marginal trace line, and the slope and threshold parameters of a logistic approximation. They then discuss issues of likelihood-equivalence and how to best use marginal trace lines in research settings to ensure local independence at the scale level. Finally, an application is presented that introduces the concept of item-level dimensionality assessment and illustrates a technique for using marginal trace lines to create unidimensional scales from multidimensional data.

sec.title: Using Bifactor Models to Account for LD
sec.p: Bifactor models are useful in a variety of scale construction scenarios. In traditional bifactor contexts, all items have nonzero loadings on two dimensions: one loading on the primary dimension and one loading on a specific dimension orthogonal to the primary dimension (Holzinger & Swineford, 1937; see Table 1). A comparison of the magnitude of loadings on the primary and secondary dimensions is typically used to characterize the strength or weakness of the particular dimension. This conventional version is commonly applied when the item set comprises multiple subscales, each with a separate score, but where a single theme underlies all the items. More recently, researchers have turned to modifications of the traditional bifactor structure to account for subsets of locally dependent items. In situations in which an item set is largely unidimensional, but with clusters of locally dependent items, a restricted bifactor model is used in which specific factors (i.e., nuisance dimensions) are estimated only to account for LD, or violations of unidimensionality (e.g., Yeatts et al., 2010); Table 2 shows an example with LD between the first two items. Often nuisance dimensions represent artifacts of the item writing process (e.g., repeated item content, phrasing) that occur for small numbers of items (e.g., doublets and triplets).

sec.title: Bifactor IRT Trace Lines for Graded Responses
sec.p: The marginal trace lines discussed in this article are based on bifactor IRT models using the multidimensional generalization of the graded response model (GRM; Samejima, 1969). The multidimensional GRM (Muraki & Carlson, 1993; Reckase, 2009) describes the probability of responding in category k or higher, where k = 0, 1, …, m:

T* traces the probability that an item response (ui ) to item i is in category k or a higher conditional on the vector of dimensions (θj), based on a vector of slope parameters (ai) that describe the strength of the relationship of the item response with each latent dimension, and intercept parameters (cik). The probability of responding in a particular category, k, is the difference between the probability of responding in category k or higher and the higher response, k + 1, or higher:

In assessing dimensionality, or the relative strength of the general factor, interpretation is focused on the model’s conditional slope parameters. However, interpreting the model in this manner is challenging and is limited to assessing the probability of response on one dimension conditional on the model’s other dimension(s). The difficulty is that a slope on θ1 (or the general factor in the bifactor case) does not indicate the marginal relation between an item response and θ1, but rather the relation between an item response with θ1 at any specific location on θ2. Hence, interpreting the relation between the item and the primary dimension may be confusing or misleading, because it depends on the magnitude of the secondary slope. For example, consider the case of two items with slopes on the primary and secondary dimension: Item 1 with a1 = 3 and a2 = 2, and Item 2 with a1 = 4 and a2 = 3. While the primary dimension slope is stronger in magnitude for Item 2 that is offset by a stronger secondary dimension, as will be seen for this example, the net effect is a nearly identical marginal relationship with the primary dimension for both items. Such occurrences are not infrequent and clearly present an interpretive challenge even for those familiar with bifactor IRT models.

sec.title: Marginal Trace Lines
sec.p: What is needed for clear interpretation is a unidimensional-equivalent marginal trace line. Ip (2010a, 2010b) noted that to obtain the marginal trace line for the general factor (θ1), one must integrate over the specific dimension for each item. For example, in a multidimensional IRT (MIRT) model, the marginal trace line for the general dimension is

In this two-dimensional example, the product of the conditional trace surface from Equation 2, Ti(θ1, θ2), and the univariate normal distribution N(0,1), integrated across the secondary dimension (θ2), is the primary dimension marginal trace line for θ1, TMarginal. In other words, the marginal trace line is obtained by weighting the trace surface by the normal distribution and integrating out the nuisance dimension. In practice, this integral may be approximated computationally using quadrature.

To obtain the marginal threshold estimates for the logistic approximations of the marginal trace line for the primary dimension, the GRM intercept parameters are transformed for each dimension of interest after accounting for all other dimensions. Repeating this process for the nuisance dimension yields a different set of location parameters and may be helpful in understanding the compensatory nature of the model.

sec.title: The Magnitude of Marginal Slope Parameters
sec.p: Because marginal slope parameters provide a more interpretable metric for the primary dimension response probabilities than MIRT conditional slope parameters, it may be of some interest to summarize the relationship between conditional slope parameters and the resulting marginal slope parameter. Consider the magnitude of the marginal slope for some simple bifactor MIRT models that have equal conditional a1 (General) and a2 (Nuisance) slope parameters (Figure 1).

sec.p: For illustrative purposes, horizontal gray lines indicate increases in the marginal slope of 0.2 units, and correspond to marginal slopes of 1.1, 1.3, and 1.5. In general, when conditional slopes are weak (e.g., when aConditional is almost 1.5), the marginal slope is also weak and only slightly less than the conditional slopes (aMarginal = 1.1). To achieve equal gains in the marginal slope parameter requires increasingly large changes in the conditional slopes as the maximum value of the marginal slope (approximately 1.7 for equal conditional slopes) is approached.2

Figure 2 provides a more complete illustration for the relationship between conditional and marginal slope parameters for two-dimensional bifactor models. The relationship is reasonably linear except for extremely high values of slopes on θ1 and low values of slopes on θ2, which result in marginal slopes that increase rapidly. This phenomenon continues as a1 increases and a2 approaches zero.

sec.title: Evaluating Joint-Likelihoods From the Marginal Trace Lines and Bifactor Model
sec.p: At first glance, an implication of Equation 4 is that marginalizing over the specific dimensions “takes care of” nuisance dimensionality, and that the resulting item parameters can be used as if they were generated from a traditional unidimensional IRT model to characterize the relationship of the item response with the primary dimension. While the marginal relationship between each item response and the primary dimension is captured by the marginal trace lines, it is not as simple as stating that the marginal trace lines entirely account for nuisance multidimensionality identified by the bifactor model. In other words, it would be incorrect to obtain the logistic approximation item parameters from marginal trace lines for all items in a bifactor model and then treat these as one would a set of unidimensional item parameters.

This issue is best understood by evaluating how the joint-likelihoods are computed when using the marginal trace lines. The item-level likelihood that is computed by integrating over the nuisance dimension for each item’s trace surface corrects the relationship for each individual item, and is the proper single-item likelihood, but using marginal item parameters from multiple items within a particular specific factor to compute the joint-likelihood still leaves the presence of the nuisance dimension at the level of the subset of items from that particular dimension. To illustrate, it is useful to examine the computational differences of the joint-likelihood computed using marginal trace lines to the same joint-likelihood computed from Cai’s (2010b) two-tier algorithm for bifactor models.

Consider a bifactor model for binary responses to items that are influenced by a primary dimension θ1 and K secondary dimensions θj. Cai (2010b) noted that the contribution to the marginal likelihood may be approximated by a sum over Q quadrature points:

where Lk is the bifactor likelihood formed as the product of the θ1 and θj trace surfaces for responses to items on the kth secondary dimension. The product of these Lk likelihoods then forms the bifactor model’s joint-likelihood for the primary dimension (L1). To understand the differences in the joint-likelihoods between the two techniques, it is helpful to first consider how the secondary dimension-specific likelihoods (i.e., the marginal likelihoods per secondary dimension) are computed from a set of responses to items on a secondary dimension k:

Here the bifactor algorithm computes the marginal likelihood by integrating over the secondary dimension for all items belonging to a particular secondary dimension at once. The product of E1k over K secondary dimensions forms the joint-likelihood for the primary dimension as shown in Equation 9.

By comparison, consider the likelihood in Equation 10 and the nearly equivalent likelihood function that is the product of the logistic approximations of marginal trace lines. For the marginal trace line approach, the product is taken over all items (from all K secondary dimensions) in forming the contribution to the joint-likelihood:
where instead of taking that product of each secondary dimension E1k (Equation 10), L*1 is the joint-likelihood computed from the product of the marginal trace lines for all the items:
Here, Tmarginal represents the marginal trace line from Equation 4 computed using Gaussian quadrature, and the product of the marginal trace lines results in the univariate likelihood function L*1.

The disparity in the techniques results in (for multiple items within a given secondary dimension) nonequivalent joint-likelihoods. For each secondary dimension, the bifactor algorithm simultaneously computes the integral of all items belonging to a particular secondary dimension, and then takes the product of those likelihoods to compute the joint-likelihood Li. In contrast, the steps are partially reversed for the marginal trace line approach, in which the integral for each individual trace surface regardless of the item’s secondary dimension is evaluated, and then the product of the integrals becomes the joint-likelihood L*1. Note that the computation of the marginal trace line is correct in that it is the marginalized relationship between the item response and the primary dimension (in other words, on an item-by-item basis the likelihoods from the bifactor model and marginal trace line methods are equivalent), but taking the product of multiple marginal trace lines within a particular secondary dimension partially ignores the LD within each secondary dimension if it is done as though it was the product of multiple locally dependent items.

sec.title: An Illustration of Equivalent and Nonequivalent Joint-Likelihoods
sec.p: The effect of partially ignoring LD results in a slight difference between the joint-likelihood computed using the bifactor algorithm (Li) and the product of the marginal trace lines across dimensions (L*1). The extent of the difference between the two likelihoods is compounded when there are many items within each secondary dimension and many secondary dimensions. Because the marginal from a likelihood computed from multiple items within a secondary dimension (the bifactor approach) is not the same as the product of the marginal trace lines (the marginal trace line approach), Eik is not the same as Tmarginal. However, when only a single item is selected from each secondary dimension, then Lk from the bifactor algorithm is simply the item’s trace surface, which is identical to the trace surface used in the marginal trace line, and the expected score for the primary dimension in the bifactor algorithm, Eik, is equivalent to the marginal trace line, Tmarginal. Hence, strictly speaking, to construct a unidimensional set of items that accounts for LD using the marginal trace line approach, only a single item can be selected from each specific dimension.3

To illustrate the differences between Eik and Tmarginal, in the case of either ignoring or accounting for LD, consider a brief six-item example with dichotomous responses where each item is in a doublet pair (the model in Table 1). For simplicity, assume all θ1 slopes are 3.0, all θ2 slopes are 2.0, and the thresholds are fixed at 0. Suppose one is interested in scoring the primary dimension. The marginal slope parameter is 1.94 for each item. If the joint-likelihoods for the bifactor and marginal trace line techniques are compared for a response pattern with positive responses to all items, clear differences in the two methods emerge.

The difference in likelihoods (Figure 3) illustrates the effect of using only marginal trace lines to account for LD. For this example, the effect of ignoring the multidimensionality is fairly minor as the scale is short (six items), with three secondary dimensions, and only two items per dimension. In situations in which the departure from unidimensionality is greater, the discrepancy between the marginal likelihood and the bifactor likelihood may increase. The severity of this effect depends on a number of aspects of the data and the model, including the number of items per specific factor, and the strength of the slopes on the nuisance dimension, both of which indicate increasingly multidimensional items. Close inspection of Figure 3 also reveals that the likelihood function appears steeper when using the marginal trace lines. When used across many items and dimensions, this effect is magnified and mistakenly leads to the impression that the likelihood function is steep, which results in IRT scaled scores that are shifted toward the extreme ends of the distribution and standard errors that suggest more precision than is present, not unlike the effect of ignoring LD in univariate IRT models (Thissen, Steinberg, & Mooney, 1989). This is the effect of partially ignoring LD.

caption.p: Nonequivalent joint marginal likelihoods for six items exhibiting pairwise LD computed (correctly) and (incorrectly) using marginal trace lines

sec.p: However, these effects can be corrected if only a single item is used per specific dimension, in which case Eik will be equivalent to Tmarginal because the integration occurs for the same trace surface. In other words, the expected score curve on the primary dimension for a single item from a secondary dimension Eik is the marginal trace line Tmarginal. Thus, when constructing unidimensional test scores, selecting a single item from each secondary dimension produces equivalent marginal likelihoods, and any difference in IRT scores or SDs will be due entirely to the logistic approximation. Figure 4 illustrates the correction to the marginal likelihood that occurs when only a single item is selected from each secondary dimension in the six-item example, resulting in identical three-item marginal likelihoods.

caption.p: Equivalent joint marginal likelihoods for three items, one from each LD pair, computed using bifactor computations and using marginal trace lines

sec.title: Application: Using Marginal Trace Lines to Create a Content-Diverse Short Form
sec.p: A goal of the current application is to use the marginal trace line techniques described in the preceding sections to demonstrate a method for developing content-diverse short forms that efficiently provide scores measuring the primary dimension. This application uses a version of the 35-item Dimensions of Change in TC (Therapeutic Community) Treatment Instrument (DCI-A; Edelen, Tucker, Stucky, Butler, & Muehlbach, under review) that was administered to 442 adolescents in residential substance-abuse treatment programs. The DCI-A is a revision to the original adult-specific scale (DCI; Orlando et al., 2006).

For the current analyses, the original five-factor CFA model for the DCI-A (Edelen et al., in press) was recast as a bifactor IRT model with one general and five specific factors. The specific factors consist of Treatment Motivation (10 items), Problem Recognition (6 items), Family Relations (7 items), Personal Development (6 items), and Social Network (6 items). To obtain full-informational maximum likelihood IRT item parameters, these factors were estimated as specific factors using the two-tier algorithm for bifactor models in IRTPRO (Cai, du Toit, & Thissen, 2011; Table 3). An assessment of model fit indices was made by reestimating the bifactor model in Mplus (Muthén & Muthén, 1998-2010) using WLSMV estimation for ordered categorical responses. The model was found to closely approximate the data (root mean square error of approximation [RMSEA] = .060, comparative fit index [CFI] = .926, TLI = .917).

sec.p: Scale developers wanted a short form to represent the primary dimension, so the question then became, “From these secondary factors, which item(s) should be selected to maximize the relation to the general dimension and minimize the impact of the nuisance dimensions?” For this situation, a variant of the Explained Common Variance (ECV) statistic proved useful as an index of unidimensionality (Reise, Moore, & Haviland, 2010; ten Berge & Socan, 2004). ECV is the percentage of common variance across all items that is explained by the general dimension:

where λGen is the bifactor loading on the general dimension and λSpec is the bifactor loading on the given specific factor k. While typically used to assess dimensionality at the scale level, considering ECV for a single item (i.e., I-ECV; see Table 3) provides the extent to which an item’s responses are accounted for by variation on the latent general dimension alone, and thus acts as an assessment of unidimensionality at the individual item level.

Recalling from the previous section that described the nonequivalence in joint-likelihoods when multiple marginal trace lines are used per secondary dimension, using the I-ECV values to identify items with relatively weak relationships with the secondary dimensions compared with the primary dimension serves to indicate those items for which the local independence assumption most nearly holds for the joint-likelihoods. For instance, within a given cluster of items, if multiple items have I-ECV values approaching 1.0, the effect of the secondary dimension may be sufficiently weak to relax the rule of selecting only a single item per dimension, as they may be collectively nearly unidimensional. In such instances, it is possible that the violation of the local independence assumption can be assumed to be minor.

Guided by these principles a seven-item content-balanced short form was created from the bifactor model by selecting individual items from each secondary factor. Table 3 provides the results by rank-ordering the items according to the magnitude of the I-ECV within each secondary factor. From each secondary factor, the item with the highest I-ECV value was retained for the short form, or in the case of the first secondary factor, the items with the three highest values were retained, as they had I-ECV values that indicate near-unidimensionality. This item selection process resulted in a short form with items that balance strong relationships with the general factor and weak relationships with the secondary factor. For the seven-item short form, GRM item parameters were estimated for the logistic approximations of the marginal trace lines using the techniques described earlier (Table 4).4

sec.p: Technically, allowing three items to remain from a single secondary factor is violating the assumption of local independence (although fit indices suggest a unidimensional model). In the present case, the two additional items that were retained from the Treatment Motivation secondary factor had I-ECV values of 0.94 and 0.95 and corresponding secondary bifactor loadings of less than 0.20. To understand how much LD is produced by using both LD items in the seven-item short form, the authors computed IRT scale scores and posterior standard deviations from summed scores (Thissen, Pommerich, Billeaud, & Williams, 1995) using both the marginal trace lines and the bifactor algorithm. For the marginal trace line method, the recursive algorithm treats all the items as though they are unidimensional; the likelihoods are formed from the products of all the marginal trace lines, ignoring the fact that three of the items were originally on the same secondary factor. However, the recursive algorithm for the bifactor method takes into account the LD of the three items by using the expected score within each specific dimension in the computation of the joint-likelihood. Because the marginal trace line technique is ignoring the LD for the three items on the same secondary factor, the result could give the appearance of overly weighting these items, which can lead to lower score standard errors and more extreme scale scores.

Table 5 indicates that for this particular short form, which includes two “extra” items from the Treatment Motivation secondary dimension, both with I-ECV values of about 0.95, there are only very slight consequences of the violation of the local independence assumption. There is a slight tendency for the marginal trace lines to result in more extreme scores (the maximum difference in expected a posterior (EAP) across summed scores was 0.11) and slightly lower posterior standard deviations (the maximum difference in SDs across summed scores was 0.01), but the overall impact is minimal. In fact, when comparing marginal reliability, an aggregate of score precision across the latent trait, the values for the marginal trace lines and bifactor model are nearly identical (.818 and .813, respectively).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Despite recent computational advances that make fitting multidimensional models more feasible (see Cai, 2010a, 2010b), there is still a demand for unidimensional scales with straightforward scoring protocols. This article demonstrates that in situations in which bifactor models are used to analyze large item sets, using marginal trace lines may be a useful approach for creating unidimensional scales and short forms. The authors have also demonstrated that, while in most instances, only a single item should be retained per cluster to represent the content of that particular secondary dimension, this limitation actually has the positive consequence of creating unidimensional scales that are composites of items representing all of the model’s secondary dimensions, which leads to short forms measuring broad content domains.

The utility of these techniques can be viewed both as a correction for violations of LD and as a technique to identify unidimensional items from a multidimensional scale. For scale development scenarios in which an item set is largely unidimensional with some minor multidimensionality, and is fitted with a restricted bifactor model, the methods proposed here are ideal for accounting for such LD without changing the content of the primary dimension and while preserving the majority of the scale’s items. This approach of selecting a single item from each secondary dimension in a restricted bifactor model was used by the pediatric PROMIS (Patient Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System) project to develop a series of item banks (e.g., DeWitt et al., 2011; Irwin et al., in press; Varni et al., 2010; Yeatts et al., 2010; etc.).

Alternatively, as in the application here, these same techniques may be used for item sets where multidimensionality is known and expected, and fitted with a complete bifactor model. It should be noted that using the marginal trace line techniques in such situations is only justifiable when a “global” construct is desired or, rather, when a unidimensional short form is desired that samples content from the various dimensions without necessarily being overly representative of any single dimension. While the bifactor model may be informative regarding the appropriateness of a global short form, the issue remains largely substantive.

Strictly speaking, using multiple marginal trace lines from a given secondary dimension partially violates the assumption of local independence and results in varying degrees of exaggerated score precision claims. Although a full investigation into the “robustness” of the marginal trace line technique to violations of LD is beyond the scope of the current work, preliminary evidence indicates that minor violations lead to trivial differences in score estimates and precision, although the effect is magnified for long tests with many clusters, or perhaps more importantly, in situations in which the secondary factor is particularly strong in relation to the primary dimension. As the use of multidimensional models and marginal item response functions becomes more widespread in scale development and scoring, additional work is needed to uncover the relationship between the testing scenario and the degree of local independence violation when multiple marginal trace lines are used per nuisance dimension.

However, the authors have also demonstrated that in special cases, multiple marginal trace lines can be used from a given secondary factor with little consequence. Their brief examination revealed that when I-ECV values are large in magnitude, the deleterious effect of using multiple marginal trace lines within a factor on LD is negligible. While this examination used I-ECV as a proxy for dimensionality, the I-ECV could also be used in conjunction with the marginal trace lines to identify not only a set of unidimensional items (according to the I-ECV) but also a set of items strongly measuring the primary dimension (according to the marginal trace lines). However, these findings are preliminary and do not address issues such as the number of items per secondary dimension, strength of the general dimension, or the total number of items on the scale. All of these factors are expected to influence the utility of the I-ECV in selecting unidimensional item sets. Further research is needed before I-ECV value guidelines can be suggested.

Regarding the use of the logistic distribution to approximate the normal CDF, Haley (1952) noted that the two never differ by probability values greater than .01. Furthermore, Ip (2010b) provided a graphical illustration comparing marginal and logistic approximations that suggest close correspondence. In the authors’ experience, across a wide range of marginals, the maximum difference in probability between the marginal and logistic approximation of the trace line is never more than about ±.01. Given this close correspondence, it appears a logistic approximation is sufficiently accurate for most uses.

For bifactor multidimensional item response theory (MIRT) models with the conditional slopes constrained to be equal on two dimensions, the marginal slope is bounded by the logistic scaling constant. That is, as the conditional slopes increase, the item variance accounted for becomes nearly 50% for each dimension. Using Equations 4 and 5, if the item variance explained is 50%, then the resulting marginal corresponds to the scaling constant (here, 1.7), or a factor loading of about 0.707.
It will later be seen that this restriction may be relaxed without much loss when the nuisance dimensionality accounted for by an item set is weak.

To ensure this item selection process resulted in a unidimensional scale, the authors fit the resulting seven items to a single factor model using WLSMV in Mplus. Not surprisingly, the seven items closely fit a unidimensional model (root mean square error of approximation [RMSEA] = .052, comparative fit index [CFI] = .991, TLI = .986). Moreover, using the factor loadings from the original bifactor model, these seven items result in an Explained Common Variance (ECV) value of 0.92, providing further evidence of unidimensionality.
